children.name: Cargo.lock
children.annotation: The code is a Rust `Cargo.toml` lock file, which is generated automatically by Cargo, Rust's package manager and build system. It is not meant to be manually edited. The file lists the packages or dependencies needed for a Rust project. This particular lock file specifies three Rust packages: "calc" (version 0.1.0) which depends on "itertools", "either" (version 1.6.1) fetched from a specified source with a given checksum, and "itertools" (version 0.10.0), which depends on "either" and is also sourced from the same registry with its own checksum.
children.content:
# This file is automatically @generated by Cargo.
# It is not intended for manual editing.
[[package]]
name = "calc"
version = "0.1.0"
dependencies = [
 "itertools",
]

[[package]]
name = "either"
version = "1.6.1"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"
checksum = "e78d4f1cc4ae33bbfc157ed5d5a5ef3bc29227303d595861deb238fcec4e9457"

[[package]]
name = "itertools"
version = "0.10.0"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"
checksum = "37d572918e350e82412fe766d24b15e6682fb2ed2bbe018280caa810397cb319"
dependencies = [
 "either",
]

children.name: Cargo.toml
children.annotation: The code is a `Cargo.toml` manifest file for a Rust project. It specifies the package information including the name "calc", version "0.1.0", authors, and Rust edition "2018". Under the `[dependencies]` section, it lists dependencies required for the project, in this case, the "itertools" crate version "0.10". This configuration allows Cargo, Rust's package manager, to build and manage the project's dependencies.
children.content:
[package]
name = "calc"
version = "0.1.0"
authors = ["Henry Boisdequin <65845077+henryboisdequin@users.noreply.github.com>"]
edition = "2018"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[dependencies]
itertools = "0.10"

children.name: README.md
children.annotation: The code outlines instructions for running a simple command-line calculator written in Rust. It specifies that you need to clone the repository, have Rust and Cargo installed, navigate to the project directory, and execute `cargo run` to run the calculator. To run tests, you can execute `cargo test`. The calculator allows performing basic arithmetic operations via the command line. Note that the specific implementation details of the calculator are not provided here.
children.content:
Simple command-line calculator in Rust.

## To Run

1. Clone this repository

2. Make sure you have Rust and cargo installed

3. Cd into the project directory and type `cargo run`

4. To test: run `cargo test`

children.name: calc.rs
children.annotation: The given code is written in Rust and defines a simple calculator struct `Calc`, which provides methods to perform basic arithmetic operations on vectors of floating-point numbers. The `add`, `sub`, `mul`, and `div` methods respectively sum, subtract, multiply, and divide all elements in the provided vector. The `sub` and `div` methods utilize `itertools::Itertools` to chain operations from the first element, ensuring sequential arithmetic operations. In the `#[test] fn test_all_operations()` function, various test cases assert the correctness of these arithmetic operations, ensuring the `Calc` struct performs as expected. The code will output nothing unless run within a test suite, which will pass if all assertions hold true.

children.name: main.rs
children.annotation: This Rust program is a simple command-line calculator that prompts the user to input mathematical equations, which it then evaluates and prints the result. The program employs a loop to continuously accept user input until the user enters "q" to quit. It supports basic arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, indicated by the characters "+", "-", "*", and "/", respectively. Each input is parsed to extract operands and the operator. The `Calc` module contains methods (`add`, `sub`, `mul`, `div`) used to perform the calculations. When an operator is detected, the program splits the input string accordingly, parses the operands as floating-point numbers, performs the corresponding arithmetic operation, and outputs the result. The expected output includes a welcome message, interactive prompts for equations, and the computation result or exit prompt when "q" is entered.
